questions.stem: What are the main types of identification procedure under Code D?

options.text: Only video identification and identification parade
Video identification, identification parade, group identification, and confrontation
Only confrontation
Only video identification

questions.explanation: Code D sets out several identification procedures: video identification, identification parade, group identification, and confrontation. Each has specific requirements and when it should be used. Video identification is generally preferred where facilities are available.

references.cite: Code C para 1.4 and Annex E (definition of vulnerable person)

questions.stem: When is an identification procedure required under Code D?

options.text: Only if the suspect disputes they were present
When the identity of the suspect is disputed, or when a witness has given a first description and there is a known suspect
Always, for every case
Only for serious offences

questions.explanation: An identification procedure is required when: (1) the identity of the suspect is disputed, or (2) a witness has given a first description and there is a known suspect. It is not required if identity is not in issue, or if the suspect was known to the witness before the incident.

references.cite: Code D para 3.12 (when identification procedure required)
Code C para 1.4 and Annex E (definition of vulnerable person)

questions.stem: What is your role as legal representative at an identification procedure?

options.text: You have no right to attend
You have the right to be present, observe, raise objections, and ensure procedures are followed correctly
You can only attend if the police invite you
You can attend but cannot intervene

questions.explanation: As legal representative, you have the right to be present at identification procedures. Your role includes: observing to ensure procedures are fair, raising objections if procedures are not followed correctly, ensuring the suspect's rights are protected, and challenging any unfairness. Your presence is a key safeguard.

references.cite: Code D para 3.17-3.20 (legal representative at identification)
Code C para 1.4 and Annex E (definition of vulnerable person)

questions.stem: A witness identifies your client from a video identification procedure. You notice the procedure was not conducted in accordance with Code D. What should you do?

options.text: Do nothingâ€”the identification has already happened
Object immediately, record your objections, and challenge the evidence at court under s.78 PACE
Only object if your client is convicted
Accept the identification as valid

questions.explanation: If an identification procedure breaches Code D, you must object immediately, record your objections (in writing if possible), and challenge the admissibility of the identification evidence at court under s.78 PACE. Breaches can render identification evidence unreliable and unfair, potentially leading to exclusion.

references.cite: Code D para 3.17-3.20 (legal representative at identification)

questions.stem: What safeguards must be in place for a video identification procedure?

options.text: No specific safeguards are required
The video must show at least 8 similar-looking people, the suspect's image must not stand out, and the procedure must be recorded
Only the suspect needs to be shown
Safeguards are optional

questions.explanation: Video identification must include safeguards: at least 8 similar-looking people (foils), the suspect's image must not stand out (same position, similar appearance), the procedure must be recorded, and the legal representative has the right to be present and object. These safeguards ensure fairness and reliability.

references.cite: Code C para 1.4 and Annex E (definition of vulnerable person)
